div1.p: To whom he sold the negros?
Answer. I hear James Singlekins say that he sold James Charlton the two youngest, Elena & Uris
Question by same where was James Stephens living when you came to Virginia, and what was his circumstance?
Answer. He was living in he South Fake of Roanoke on a plantation he had rented from John Barnet and had a small field in corn

Question by same. No you know a not know of any thing of any paper writinh having been pals between the embracting parties in New York? (The Defendant by his objected to this question being answered ? the writing was produced).
Answer. There was a paper passed from Jacob Lawrence to James Singlekins, after yhr bargain was concluded between them, and the recipe had given her evident.
Question. What was the character of this paper writing?
Answer. I took it to bea Bill of Sale, and was a --- --- --- to it. It bound Jacob Lawrence and his heirs to support the title of the Negroes, to Hames Singlekins, and his heirs.
Question by same. Do you know what has become of the Bill of Sale?
Answer. I do not
Question by same Did or did not James Singlekins tell you all about this affair either in the State if New York or shortly after your arrival in the State of Virginia?
Answer. I have said what he told me. I do not need bei of his telling me any thing else about this affair.
Question by same. Did James Singlekins ever say any thing to you about the solvency or insolvency of Jacob Lawrence, and if any thing, what?
Answer. Since this writ was institute, and the answer

of the Negroes obtaining their freedom got shrsf snf yhst James Singlekins would be thereby. I think he enquired of me about the solvency of Jacob Lawrence. He might or he moght not. I cannot be positive
Question by Defendant. Dud or did not James Singlekins tell you that he was acting as the agent of James Stpehens in the purchase of the negroes?
Answer. I cannot say positively that he did not. But he told me he was the agent in selling the skins.
Question by Plffs Counsel. When and where did you last see the Bill of Sale
Answer. About three years ago I saw it in the possession of James Singlekins. His wife showed it to me. I t was written by my father, and witnessed by him, James Stephens and myself.

Question by defendant. Did or did you not state to some person since the trial at Giles Count House that the Bill of Sale referred to above was execute too James Singlekins as the agent of James Stephens?
Answer. I do not know whether I did or not
Signed Thos. Lawrence

Two depositions of Elijah Meacham in the words and signed following to wit
--- 4h Octobe 1832

I knew old Flora the mother of the Plaintiffs in Connecticut in the year 1778, and in which year for the last time I saw her there. The next time I saw her, she was at sir James Charlton's in Montgomery County, which was one year before the birth of Robert Craig now present, and I believe it to be fortyone years ago. As to there freedom. I know except by hearsay, that in a conversation I had with James Charlton about one year after I came to this Country, believed to be forty years ago, about the freedom of Flora. James Charlton said if she obtained her freedom, it would not hurt him
so bad, but it would James Singlekins, and he did not want to do that. This conversation took place at Chaistinasberg .about one year after I came to this Country.
Question by John McC Saylor about Defendant. Did you ever tell Flora that she was emtitled to her freddom by the laws of the State if Connecticut?
Answer. I did not.
Signed Elija Meacham
2nd deposition of Elijah Meacham. taken 4h November 1834.
Question by Plainntiffs counsel. What do you know about Unis Ilena paupers who are sueing for their freedom?

Answer. I know old Flora who was related to the mother of Morris & Cena in Hartford County in the state of Connecticut. She was then owned by one Benjamin Scott. The next time I saw her was about the of 1791 in the possession of James Charlton on Meadow Creek in the County of Montgomery. On a certain occasion I was at James Charlton's, where he saw Flora the mother of the Plaintiffs. Tied to the bed post. I told him I heard that he was a going to send the negroes away. He said to me that he never talked of them. But Jame Singlekins saif he would them to Hell before they should get their freedom. James Charlton said the damn old bitch had been to Ezekiel Howard Esq, to get a warrant for her freedom. that Howard did not grant it, and he hoped no magistrate ever would.
Sugned Elijah Meacham
